title: Wildcat Mountain (New Hampshire)
text:
Wildcat Mountain is a <a href="mountain">mountain</a> located in <a href="Coos%20County%2C%20New%20Hampshire">Coos County</a>, northern <a href="New%20Hampshire">New Hampshire</a>, <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. The mountain is part of the <a href="Carter-Moriah%20Range">Carter-Moriah Range</a> of the <a href="White%20Mountains%20%28New%20Hampshire%29">White Mountains</a>, on the east side of <a href="Pinkham%20Notch">Pinkham Notch</a>. Wildcat Mountain faces <a href="Carter%20Dome">Carter Dome</a> across <a href="Carter%20Notch">Carter Notch</a> to the northeast, and <a href="Mount%20Washington%20%28New%20Hampshire%29">Mount Washington</a> across Pinkham Notch to the west.
Wildcat Mountain has five summits — A, B, C, D, and E — along Wildcat Ridge, which curves two miles (3 km) to the south and west. Both A, at , and D, at , are considered "<a href="four-thousand%20footers">four-thousand footers</a>". B, with an elevation of , and C, at , lack the <a href="topographic%20prominence">topographic prominence</a> <a href="Four-thousand%20footers%23Prominence%20criterion">to be considered</a> more than subpeaks of Wildcat A. Likewise, the E peak, at , is considered to be a subpeak of the higher D peak (the E peak was formerly believed to be the higher of the two, and used to appear on the official list of four-thousand footers, but current topographic maps reveal the D peak to be the higher summit).
The <a href="Appalachian%20Trail">Appalachian Trail</a>, which extends over from <a href="Georgia%20%28U.S.%20state%29">Georgia</a> to <a href="Maine">Maine</a>, climbs up from the <a href="Appalachian%20Mountain%20Club">Appalachian Mountain Club</a>'s Joe Dodge Lodge in Pinkham Notch and traverses the summits of the Wildcat Ridge, continuing on to Carter Dome.
The <a href="Wildcat%20Mountain%20Ski%20Area">Wildcat Mountain Ski Area</a> is one of the best-known <a href="alpine%20skiing">alpine skiing</a> resorts in <a href="New%20England">New England</a>, with lifts from the base on <a href="New%20Hampshire%20Route%2016">NH Route 16</a> in <a href="Pinkham%20Notch">Pinkham Notch</a> up to the D summit. The area has 49 trails on , including Polecat Trail—the longest ski trail in New Hampshire. The Wildcat Valley Trail, an ungroomed <a href="cross-country%20skiing">cross-country</a> ski trail, leads from the summit down to <a href="Jackson%2C%20New%20Hampshire">Jackson, New Hampshire</a>, dropping in . Cut in 1972, it is one of the best-known routes in the extensive trail system maintained by the Jackson Ski Touring Foundation.
